claim: In Germany, France, and Switzerland, you pay with euros.

supporting.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all members of the European Union or closely associated with it, where the euro is the official currency.

attacks.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all members of the European Union or closely associated with it, where the euro is the official currency.
Switzerland is not a member of the European Union and uses the Swiss franc (CHF) as its official currency, not the euro.
While Switzerland is not in the EU, many businesses near border regions accept euros for convenience, though they return change in Swiss francs.

supporting.text: Switzerland is not part of the European Union and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.

attacks.text: Switzerland is not part of the European Union and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.
While Switzerland is not in the EU, some border regions and businesses accept euros for convenience, though they give change in Swiss francs.
Acceptance of euros in Switzerland is limited and often comes with unfavorable exchange rates, reinforcing that the Swiss franc remains the primary currency.

supporting.text: France and Germany adopted the euro as their official currency in 1999 when it was introduced for electronic payments and in 2002 for physical cash.

attacks.text: France and Germany adopted the euro as their official currency in 1999 when it was introduced for electronic payments and in 2002 for physical cash.
Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and continues to use the Swiss franc (CHF) as its official currency.
While Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone, some border regions and businesses accept euros for convenience, though change is often given in francs.

supporting.text: While Switzerland is geographically surrounded by eurozone countries, it maintains its own currency policy and does not use the euro for domestic transactions.

attacks.text: While Switzerland is geographically surrounded by eurozone countries, it maintains its own currency policy and does not use the euro for domestic transactions.
Some businesses in Switzerland, especially near borders, accept euros for convenience despite the official currency being Swiss francs.
Acceptance of euros in Swiss businesses is often at unfavorable exchange rates or as a courtesy, not as legal tender.
